persona.name: Anna
persona.activities:
Anna is in the final year of an undergraduate medical degree. Breathing difficulties, coupled with a very mild form of Cerebral Palsy mean that some of her motor skills are limited and she is prone to bouts of fatigue. Because of her restricted mobility, Anna is dependent on the use of a wheel-chair.
Despite her disability, Anna is keen on socialising, and lives in an adapted halls of residence at her university, so she can get out and meet people.
persona.attitudes:
Although Anna had problems studying with her disabilities in school, her expectations about the accessibility of places, processes, and things have been raised during her time at university. These were raised in line with her desire to be more independent. Her local authority provides her access to a Personal Assistant when she occasionally needs help with shopping or other physically demanding activities, and she finds that many shops and places around university are becoming more accessible. As a result, Anna expects software and systems to be accessible enough for her to use.
As the world around her has become more accessible, Anna has grown to dislike being type-casted because she relies on a wheel-chair. When she can, as much for exercise as anything else, she will try to walk short distances without a wheel-chair. Moreover, as her graduation approaches, she has become increasingly wary of highlighting her disability too greatly. With the current economic crisis, Anna is concerned she might miss out on jobs if her CV or an application form suggests she might be too much of a burden.
persona.aptitudes:
Anna's desire for independence has given her a sharp eye for identifying ways that technology can improve her mobility. To reduce her reliance on her Personal Assistant constantly visiting her, she uses her mobile to keep in touch with her if she needs something. She also uses an electric wheelchair to get around, and is on the look out for any technology which might improve her studies and way of life, even if she has to pay for it herself because her local authority will not.
Anna realises, however, that she does not live in a perfect world and needs to forward plan if she does anything which she thinks might be out of the ordinary. If Anna needs to take a bus, she tries to find out if she can take a wheel-chair on it before she ventures out. Anna also tries to find out if new shops are accessible before she first visits them, especially when buying clothes; she does not want to find something she likes only to discover that there is nowhere accessible to try it on.
persona.motivations:
Being disabled, Anna often needs to deal with a lot of bureaucracy to get the care she needs, and would love for some of this to be automated. She is convinced that technology can help her reduce the amount of forms she invariably needs to complete to get her benefits, or the number of people she has to deal with in local government or her university to resolve issues which occasionally crop up.
Despite her self confidence, Anna always needs to think about what happens when things go wrong. Getting wheel-chair problems when out and about can leave her stranded because she struggles when walking more than a short distance.

document_reference.name: limited motor skills
document_reference.excerpt: The CP also affects my fine motor skills - I can't write very fast, and I need extra thinking time in exams in order for my brain to get what I should be doing.

document_reference.name: has a mild form for Cerebral Palsy
document_reference.excerpt: I have Cerebral Palsy.....The most obvious way it affects my life is in my walking. I can't walk as fast as the average person, and I get tired very easily.

document_reference.name: looking to make friends
document_reference.document: Starting Uni In A Wheelchair forum post
document_reference.excerpt: I'm also worried about the social side of things. I didn't have many friends at high school, but I'm hoping to change that.

document_reference.name: lives in adapted halls of residence
document_reference.document: Starting Uni In A Wheelchair forum post
document_reference.excerpt: I didn't attend freshers week due to my adapted halls not being ready.

document_reference.name: can walk short distances
document_reference.excerpt: But I can get out of a chair and walk short distances if necessary...

document_reference.name: wary of highlighting own disability
document_reference.excerpt: Haven't been employed for a long time but I'm very wary of actually applying for work (especially in the current economic climate) as a result of my disability.

document_reference.name: dislikes wheelchair stereotypes
document_reference.document: Disabled Students Society - new icon? forum post
document_reference.excerpt: A wheelchair isn't a disability, a disability is what puts you in the wheelchair. The whole point of a wheelchair is to make your life easier. Yes, in relation to 'normal' people it's difficult and awkward, but they give mobility to people who would be unable to move otherwise. That's not really that hindering at all.

document_reference.name: receives local authority help
document_reference.excerpt: I also applied for DSA. About a month after applying for DSA, I received a letter confirming that they'd help, which was quite a relief!

document_reference.name: access to a personal assistant
document_reference.excerpt: For me, as a wheelchair user, I had a personal assistant right through induction week (24/7) but them afterwards that I wanted by own space which they respected....

document_reference.name: finds places are usually accessible
document_reference.excerpt: everything is fairly accessible and I can get into the majority of shops with people around me often being fairly considerate and helping if I go shopping etc.

document_reference.name: strives for independence
document_reference.excerpt: ...disabled students can become more independent in their environment.

document_reference.name: expects accessible course material
document_reference.excerpt: Regardless the type of his/her disability, the student expects all course material to be optimally accessible.

document_reference.name: uses acessible public transport
document_reference.excerpt: ... avoid me needing to travel on non-wheelchair accessible buses.

document_reference.name: plans travel in advance
document_reference.excerpt: ...Trains are even worse, the ramps are ridiciously steep and despite booking assistance in advance....

document_reference.name: looks for accessible shops
document_reference.excerpt:
I've found lots of shops with steps to get in and no ramps as well though there are some out there that are really helpful (people have volunteered to run around and find things for me in some shops so I can rest)....
..I don't normally try on clothes in shops but had to on Friday as I needed it Satuday morning and the number of shops that didn't have disabled changing rooms was very high, I could get into the room but then couldn't shut the door, so thought about buying the item then going into the disabled toilet to try it on so could take it back if didn't fit, seemed like a lot of polava to be honest though.

document_reference.name: conscious of equipment needed to keep studying
document_reference.excerpt: ... in that time, they guy managed to work out what sort of equipment might help me out and anything else that might be useful in order for me to keep studying.
